awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Study of Synthetic and Transformational Reactions of Molecular Silver and Gold Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
Chemists routinely transform molecules using chemical reactions to make and break chemical bonds, rearranging the atoms in controlled and deliberate ways to make new and valuable molecules. The synthesis and transformation of molecular nanoparticles (10-100 times the size of most small molecules) lack that level of control and sophistication.  Professor Terry Bigioni and his research group at the University of Toledo are changing this limitation by systematically studying different types of nanoparticle reactions to learn the details of nanoparticle synthesis and transformation. By shedding light on how nanoparticles react, chemists may be able to make better nanomaterials and enable new technologies that drive the economy and help society. The fundamental nature of this work means that it can impact a broad range of fields, such as better catalysts that clean the air and conserve energy, new classes of anti-cancer and anti-viral drugs, light-emitting beacons for biomedical imaging, or energy absorbers for harvesting energy directly from the sun. Students involved in this research gain valuable skills and interdisciplinary training that is vital to strengthening our nation's economy, technical leadership, and workforce. This project includes extensive outreach activities, including the popular "Saturday Morning Science" public lecture series at the University of Toledo.

Monolayer-protected clusters (MPCs) are a class of nanoparticles that are small enough to have discrete molecular structures. Despite being a molecular species, it is still not yet possible to predict the outcome of MPC reactions. With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the NSF Chemistry Division, Professor Terry Bigioni and his research group are studying the fundamental chemical principles of noble metal MPCs (primarily gold, silver, and their alloys), to better understand reactions involving this new class of compounds. The research focuses on learning the synthetic principles of nanoparticle formation as well as the underlying concepts of nanoparticle modification and transformation using a subset of MPCs with known structures. To accomplish this, the team is developing methods to study equilibrium distributions and reaction kinetics in order to gain a more detailed picture of metal nanoparticle thermodynamics and reaction pathways. These are important steps toward establishing a predictive theory of noble metal nanoparticle reactivity and improving our ability to rationally control their structures and properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Silver monolayer-protected clusters (MPCs) are silver nanoparticles that are so small that they are molecular. This means that for a given size, each cluster is identical to the next. The Na4Ag44(p-MBA)30 silver cluster is such a molecule, with a molecular formula and structure that is the same for each and every one (see picture). Here, p-MBA is an abbreviation for an organic “ligand” molecule called para-mercaptobenzoic acid, which is attached to the silver metal core like hair on a ball – this is called the ligand shell. Those p-MBA ligands protect the silver, make it soluble in different liquid solvents, and can even control its chemical reactivity. These silver MPCs are a relatively new class of materials that could be used in a variety of applications. For silver, we are developing ways of using them to kill bacteria, which can provide news ways to help cure infections and even keep your clothes smelling fresh.

Understanding how to make and modify these clusters is an important part of the chemistry we need to learn in order to make those useful applications possible. In this project, we learned three important aspects about cluster chemistry: (1) how clusters form in chemical reactions, (2) how metal atom exchange works in the metal core, and (3) how ligand exchange works in the ligand shell.

Gold and silver MPCs have been synthesized for decades now but, surprisingly, we did not know how the chemistry worked and how they formed! In our project, we figured out that they form in a very canonical way. First, once a high enough concentration of building blocks was available, the smallest clusters formed. Then more building blocks were added to the smallest clusters, which grew into a bit bigger clusters, then a bit bigger, and so on. This finally explained the patterns we would see in MPC synthesis products, based on the availability of building blocks and the pattern of sequential growth (smallest, the next smallest, etc.). This simple insight was extremely useful and powerful in helping us design better ways of making the clusters we want.

We also worked on better understanding cluster chemistry, which included figuring out how switching out a few silver atoms for gold atoms worked (essentially the molecular version of alloying), in order to make more complex metal cores, and figuring out how and where new ligands could be switched out, in order to make more complex outer ligand shells.

We learned that the chemistry behind metal atom exchange is more complex than expected. In particular, the energetics of metal atom exchange was not at all what we expected. We expected a decrease in energy with each new gold atom substituted, but instead the pattern was complex. While we do not yet fully understand this, we did develop a plausible mechanism of substitution using sophisticated computer modeling and we also developed a methodology for studying these reactions and evaluating their energetics. The complex nature of the energetics is likely related to the electronic structure within the mixed metal core. If we can understand this, then it could help us design better catalysts.

We learned that the chemistry behind ligand exchange is controlled by the ligand’s ability to withdraw electrons from the metal cluster, which is favorable. The more electron-withdrawing the ligand is, the easier it is to exchange. This basic concept is known in other fields of chemistry as electrophilic substitution. Understanding how to modify these ligand coatings is an important part of figuring out how to make more complex coatings for more sophisticated cluster properties. And connecting our cluster chemistry to concepts in other areas of chemistry is helpful in developing a framework of how to understand cluster chemistry. We also learned that when we substitute in new types of ligands, to make a mixed ligand shell, those new ligands do not necessarily stay where they were put. This is an important aspect of ligand exchange chemistry with silver MPCs, which may impose limitations to cluster design. It may also spur new ideas on how to control where ligands go and how to limit their mobility and make them stay put.

Getting a better understanding of all of these types of chemical reactions will enable us to make more sophisticated cluster materials with the properties we need to make new technologies.
